lexUnit.name: inflate.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: to expand or cause to expand by filling with air or gas.

sentence.text: The weakness of the pound helped inflate the figures in sterling .

The porcupine fish ( opposite , top ) inflates itself by gulping in water ( or air if it has been removed from the sea ) until its body is so puffed up that its spiny scales stand out rigidly from its body and defy any killer to devour it .
If we glued little pictures of galaxies to the surface , we would see that they moved progressively further apart as we inflated the balloon .
Not only was maintaining the British war effort imposing an ever-increasing burden , but subsidies to allies seriously inflated that burden .
Arriving at the edge of the quay , Fitzroy Maclean attempted to inflate it , only to discover that it had a puncture .
She denied that the company 's approach to Mr Bond had artificially inflated the price .
These trap the air and so inflate the wing .
To stabilise the position of the tube , two balloons surrounding the anal canal were inflated ( Fig 1 ) .
Rolled up , admittedly , but those things can be opened and inflated from their gas cylinders in seconds .
After a rest of five minutes the rectal balloon was serially inflated with 10 , 20 , 40 , 60 , and 100 ml of air ( intermittent inflation ) .
It was inflated with liquid rubber monomer under its own vapour pressure .
The balloon was inflated with air in 50 ml increments .
She said Highpoint prisoners Paul Carter and Aslam Mirza had inflated some of the balloons .
She inflated his ego until he was at bursting point .
Severe winters greatly inflate the numbers of nearly all wintering wildfowl .
The remaining four fans inflate the skirt to provide the cushion that keeps the Al-88 above the sea .
Farmers took several payments for each load of produce and inflated their yield reports .
An indexation allowance can also be used to inflate or create a loss for CGT purposes .
